Author: mithro_
Content: I believe you can use the ulx3s to simulate his design.

Author: anfroholic
Content:
I guess, I was wondering if someone would be able to easily use your guy's internet facing FPGA's to validate designs somehow. 
Seems they aren't up to the task.

Author: mithro_
Content: Well, it's kind of complicated. The big issue is that the Arty has DDR3 memory but @logic destroyer's design only supports SDRAM (which is what is on the ULX3S).

Author: mithro_
Content: The actually stuff he is putting on the ASIC should work fine on both FPGAs in theory

Author: mithro_
Content: But really you want something like https://fires.im/ -- that makes the FPGA be an ASIC simulation accelerator

Author: mithro_
Content: @Andrew Wingate - I have a bunch of the high end boards which people use for things like that. But as they are like $20k USD each I'm less happy to put them randomly on the internet for anyone to access.

Author: mithro_
Content: The NeTV2 and NiteFury cards that @Tisham Dhar (CSIRO EASI) is playing with might be a good option for doing small firesim like stuff with the PCIe connection.

Author: anfroholic
Content:
Gotcha, thanks. I *correctly* assumed they weren't quite sized for the task, but figured I'd ask anyways. 
Cool to see the toolchain exists!

Author: mithro_
Content: I mean, the designs you are doing on wafer.space probably are pretty reasonable to fit on the Arty / Netv2 / ULX3S sized FPGAs.

Author: mithro_
Content: I'm guessing the NiteFury II mentioned @ https://docs.fires.im/en/latest/Getting-Started-Guides/On-Premises-FPGA-Getting-Started/RHS-Research-Nitefury-II-FPGAs.html is probably Ultrascale+ based rather than Series 7 like the original Nitefury?
